awd_abstract_narration:
Recent advances in technology allow the fabrication of very small structures with highly desirable capabilities. This enables new physical and chemical understanding (nanoscience) as well as new structures and devices that are of interest to many industries (nanotechnology). The Midwest Nano Infrastructure Corridor (MINIC) National Nanotechnology Coordinated Infrastructure (NNCI) site at the University of Minnesota will accelerate these advances by providing access to leading edge micro and nano fabrication capabilities for the research and development of nanoscience and technology. The MINIC core facilities represent more than $50M in labs and equipment as well as more than 400 man-years of staff expertise. Academic researchers can use these capabilities on an equal basis with University of Minnesota faculty. Students will travel to MINIC facilities to gain valuable hands-on experience. Entrepreneurs will enjoy low-cost access to try new ideas without having to make long-term capital equipment commitments. MINIC will support a broad spectrum of nano R&D, however it will target researchers in two new areas: the application of two-dimensional materials and the use of nano in biology and medicine. By partnering with North Dakota State University, MINIC will also enable the packaging of nano devices. This allows researchers to perform reliability testing and to incorporate these devices into complex electronic systems. MINIC will also reach out to underserved communities to increase their participation in this rapidly growing field. It will also support micro and nano laboratories at smaller schools throughout the Midwest to enable the development of nanotechnology over a broad geographic area.

MINIC will provide support to micro and nano researchers throughout the country. MINIC offers researchers access to multiple clean rooms with a full suite of fabrication equipment including state-of-the-art electron beam lithography, and extensive staff support to enable them to carry out difficult fabrication projects in a timely and cost-effective manner. To better recruit and serve external users, MINIC will add three new process Focus Areas. The first will support the deposition of a broad variety of 2D thin films, beginning with graphene and the transition metal dichalcogenides. Users will be able to build devices on top of their own substrates without the low yield and variability associated with exfoliation. MINIC will also provide new modeling tools to support this area. The second Focus Area will be led by North Dakota State University's Packaging Center, which has long-standing expertise in the area. This will enable researchers in academia and industry to economically package nanoscale devices, including difficult applications such as RF devices, MEMS, power devices, and 3D multichips. MINIC's third Focus Area will support external users working in bio nanotechnology by providing all the facilities and equipment needed to form nanoparticle suspensions, perform sizing and zeta potential measurements, use them to expose cell cultures in a BSL2 environment, and characterize the result with confocal and fluorescence microscopy. MINIC will also develop a novel outreach program to support nano science and technology labs throughout the upper Midwest.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
The Midwest Nano Infrastructure Corridor (MiNIC) is one of sixteen nodes of the National Nanotechnology Coordinated Infrastructure (NNCI), a network of open-access nanotechnology laboratory user facilities. In this award, MiNIC consisted of a partnership between two facilities: (1) The Minnesota Nano Center  (MNC) at the University of Minnesota (UMN) and the Center for Nanoscale Science and Engineering at North Dakota State University (NDSU).

The MNC is a state-of-the-art facility in two locations on the UMN Twin Cities campus that supports interdisciplinary research in nanoscience and applied nanotechnology. The Center for Nanoscale Science and Engineering is part of the Research & Technology Park on the Fargo campus of NDSU. Together they represent a broad suite of capabilities to support work in nano-scale research and development focusing on the upper Midwest. MiNIC's core facilities include more than 15,000 gross square feet including two cleanrooms, an Advanced Packaging Laboratory, and two specialty labs focusing on BioNano and Nanomaterials.

In addition to providing a general capability for nanofabrication, MiNIC included 3 focus areas on (1) Two-dimensional (2D) materials, (2) Advanced packaging, and (3) BioNano.

Throughout the course of the award, MiNIC greatly expanded the capabilities of the laboratory facilities. In all, 28 new tools were purchased or upgraded over the life of the award with a cost of $2.9M. The vast majority of the costs for this equipment were paid for by the University of Minnesota, demonstrating strong institutional support for this program. Major additions include a commercial 2D materials deposition system, plasma enhanced atomic layer deposition (PE-ALD), and a new deep trench etcher, all installed at the MNC.

Before the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, MiNIC built upon its already-strong external user base by increasing the number of external users per year by over a factor of two, from under 70 to over 140. Over 150 unique organizations have used the facility over the course of the award, with an excellent mix of academic and industrial users. MiNIC also expanded its recruitment effort for new users through our Explore Nano program. The program offset initial lab fees by new users, and has been successful in attracting a wide range of new industrial and academic users.

MiNIC acted as a hub of innovation and support for nanotechnology in the upper Midwest region and during this period, we established the Northern Nano Lab Alliance (NNLA). The NNLA is a regional network of university fabrication facilities, with the mission to help each member improve their support of academic research in applied nanotechnology. Participating institutions include South Dakota State University, Michigan Tech, University of Iowa, Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology, and others. Several other nodes of the NNCI have now adopted the NNLA model to support nanofabrication at smaller facilities within their local regions. 

MiNIC contributed to extensive scientific breakthroughs, with a total over 900 publications and conference presentations attributed to research performed in MiNIC facilities, including numerous publications in high-impact journals.

MiNIC had a major impact through its educational programs at all levels including graduate, undergraduate and K-12 students, as well as outreach to the general public. The programs encompassed a wide range of activities, including classes on nanotechnology and photolithography, summer camp hands-on courses, regular lab and cleanroom tours for a wide range of audiences, exhibits and presentations at science festivals, presentations at science teacher conferences, and public programs via science museums. The MiNIC site trained over 700 undergraduate and graduate students in cleanroom and laboratory procedures and tools, including nearly 250 from other educational institutions. Over 4 years, MiNIC ran an a two-day 2D Materials Summer School with a program consisting of both lectures and hands-on activities. This program featured external speakers from top institutions such as Stanford, Harvard, Duke, Cornell, and EPFL. Based upon the success of the program, MiNIC also initiated a Nanomedicine short course. A hands-on training session on packaging technology at NDSU was provided over three years for summer undergraduate research participants in the Idea Network for Biomedical Research (INBRE), a program to engage North Dakota American Indian students in biomedical and related research. In total, MINIC's outreach program reached over 15,000 people, including over 8,000 participant students in grades 5-12, 3,000 people as part of our public outreach programs, and 1,500 through contacts with secondary and post-secondary teachers.


Last Modified: 09/28/2022
Modified by: Steven J Koester
